dn1:1.1.2: At one time the Buddha was traveling along the road between Rājagaha and Nāḷandā together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants.
dn1:1.1.3: The wanderer Suppiya was also traveling along the same road, together with his resident pupil, the student Brahmadatta.
dn1:1.1.4: Meanwhile, Suppiya criticized the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in many ways,
dn1:1.1.5: but his pupil Brahmadatta praised them in many ways.
dn1:1.1.6: And so both tutor and pupil followed behind the Buddha and the Saṅgha of mendicants directly contradicting each other.
dn1:1.2.1: Then the Buddha took up residence for the night in the royal rest-house in Ambalaṭṭhikā together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
dn1:1.2.2: And Suppiya and Brahmadatta did likewise.
dn1:1.2.3: There too, Suppiya criticized the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in many ways,
dn1:1.2.4: but his pupil Brahmadatta praised them in many ways.
dn1:1.2.5: And so both tutor and pupil kept on directly contradicting each other.
dn1:1.3.1: Then several mendicants rose at the crack of dawn and sat together in the pavilion, where the topic of judgmentalism came up:
dn1:1.3.2: “It’s incredible, reverends, it’s amazing how the diverse convictions of sentient beings have been well deciphered by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
dn1:1.3.3: For this Suppiya criticizes the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in many ways,
dn1:1.3.4: while his pupil Brahmadatta praises them in many ways.
dn1:1.3.5: And so both tutor and pupil followed behind the Buddha and the Saṅgha of mendicants directly contradicting each other.”
dn1:1.4.1: When the Buddha found out about this discussion on judgmentalism among the mendicants, he went to the pavilion, where he sat on the seat spread out and addressed the mendicants,
dn1:1.4.2: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
dn1:1.4.3: The mendicants told him what had happened, adding,
dn1:1.4.9: “This was our conversation that was unfinished when the Buddha arrived.”
dn1:1.5.1: “Mendicants, if others criticize me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, don’t make yourselves resentful, bitter, and exasperated.
dn1:1.5.2: You’ll get angry and upset, which would be an obstacle for you alone.
dn1:1.5.3: If others were to criticize me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, and you got angry and upset, would you be able to understand whether they spoke well or poorly?”
dn1:1.6.1: “If others criticize me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, you should explain that what is untrue is in fact untrue:
dn1:1.6.2: ‘This is why that’s untrue, this is why that’s false. There’s no such thing in us, it’s not found among us.’
dn1:1.6.3: If others praise me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, don’t make yourselves thrilled, elated, and excited.
dn1:1.6.4: You’ll get thrilled, elated, and excited, which would be an obstacle for you alone.
dn1:1.6.5: If others praise me, the teaching, or the Saṅgha, you should admit that what is true is in fact true:
dn1:1.6.6: ‘This is why that’s true, this is why that’s correct. There is such a thing in us, it is found among us.’
dn1:1.7.1: When an ordinary person speaks praise of the Realized One, they speak only of trivial, trifling details of mere ethics.
dn1:1.7.2: And what are the trivial, trifling details of mere ethics that an ordinary person speaks of?
dn1:1.8.1: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up killing living creatures. He has renounced the rod and the sword. He’s scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.’
dn1:1.8.2: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.8.3: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up stealing. He takes only what’s given, and expects only what’s given. He keeps himself clean by not thieving.’
dn1:1.8.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.8.5: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up unchastity. He is chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.’
dn1:1.8.6: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.9.1: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up lying. He speaks the truth and sticks to the truth. He’s honest and dependable, and doesn’t trick the world with his words.’
dn1:1.9.2: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.9.3: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up divisive speech. He doesn’t repeat in one place what he heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, he reconciles those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.’
dn1:1.9.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.9.5: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up harsh speech. He speaks in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.’
dn1:1.9.6: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.9.7: ‘The ascetic Gotama has given up talking nonsense. His words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. He says things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.’
dn1:1.9.8: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.10.1: ‘The ascetic Gotama refrains from injuring plants and seeds.’
dn1:1.10.3: ‘He eats in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.’
dn1:1.10.4: ‘He refrains from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .’
dn1:1.10.5: ‘He refrains from attiring and adorning himself with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.’
dn1:1.10.6: ‘He refrains from high and luxurious beds.’
dn1:1.10.7: ‘He refrains from receiving gold and currency,
dn1:1.10.16: ‘He refrains from running errands and messages;
dn1:1.10.20: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.’
dn1:1.10.21: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.10.22: The shorter section on ethics is finished.
dn1:1.11.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in injuring plants and seeds.
dn1:1.11.2: These include plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds as the fifth.
dn1:1.11.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such injury to plants and seeds.’
dn1:1.11.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.12.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in storing up goods for their own use.
dn1:1.12.2: This includes such things as food, drink, clothes, vehicles, bedding, fragrance, and things of the flesh.
dn1:1.12.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from storing up such goods.’
dn1:1.12.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.13.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in seeing shows.
dn1:1.13.2: This includes such things as dancing, singing, music, performances, and storytelling; clapping, gongs, and kettledrums; beauty pageants; pole-acrobatics and bone-washing displays of the corpse-workers; battles of elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, goats, rams, chickens, and quails; staff-fights, boxing, and wrestling; combat, roll calls of the armed forces, battle-formations, and regimental reviews.
dn1:1.13.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such shows.’
dn1:1.13.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.14.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in gambling that causes negligence.
dn1:1.14.2: This includes such things as checkers with eight or ten rows, checkers in the air, hopscotch, spillikins, board-games, tip-cat, drawing straws, dice, leaf-flutes, toy plows, somersaults, pinwheels, toy measures, toy carts, toy bows, guessing words from syllables, guessing another’s thoughts, and imitating musical instruments.
dn1:1.14.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such gambling.’
dn1:1.14.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.15.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still make use of high and luxurious bedding.
dn1:1.15.2: This includes such things as sofas, couches, woolen covers—shag-piled, colorful, white, embroidered with flowers, quilted, embroidered with animals, double- or single-fringed—and silk covers studded with gems, as well as silken sheets, woven carpets, rugs for elephants, horses, or chariots, antelope hide rugs, and spreads of fine deer hide, with a canopy above and red cushions at both ends.
dn1:1.15.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such bedding.’
dn1:1.15.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.16.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
dn1:1.16.2: This includes such things as applying beauty products by anointing, massaging, bathing, and rubbing; mirrors, ointments, garlands, fragrances, and makeup; face-powder, foundation, bracelets, headbands, fancy walking-sticks or containers, rapiers, parasols, fancy sandals, turbans, jewelry, chowries, and long-fringed white robes.
dn1:1.16.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such beautification and adornment.’
dn1:1.16.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.17.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in low talk. This includes such topics as
dn1:1.17.2: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that place.
dn1:1.17.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low talk.’
dn1:1.17.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.18.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in arguments.
dn1:1.18.2: They say such things as: “You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!”
dn1:1.18.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such argumentative talk.’
dn1:1.18.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.19.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in running errands and messages.
dn1:1.19.2: This includes running errands for rulers, ministers, aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or princes who say: “Go here, go there. Take this, bring that from there.”
dn1:1.19.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such errands.’
dn1:1.19.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.20.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in deceit, flattery, hinting, and belittling, and using material things to chase after other material things.
dn1:1.20.2: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such deceit and flattery.’
dn1:1.20.3: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.20.4: The middle section on ethics is finished.
dn1:1.21.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn1:1.21.2: This includes such fields as limb-reading, omenology, divining celestial portents, interpreting dreams, divining bodily marks, divining holes in cloth gnawed by mice, fire offerings, ladle offerings, offerings of husks, rice powder, rice, ghee, or oil; offerings from the mouth, blood sacrifices, palmistry; geomancy for building sites, fields, and cemeteries; exorcisms, earth magic, snake charming, poisons; the lore of the scorpion, the rat, the bird, and the crow; prophesying lifespan, chanting for protection, and divining omens from wild animals.
dn1:1.21.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.’
dn1:1.21.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.22.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn1:1.22.2: This includes reading the marks of gems, cloth, clubs, swords, spears, arrows, bows, weapons, women, men, boys, girls, male and female bondservants, elephants, horses, buffaloes, bulls, cows, goats, rams, chickens, quails, monitor lizards, rabbits, tortoises, or deer.
dn1:1.22.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.’
dn1:1.22.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.23.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn1:1.23.2: This includes making predictions that the king will march forth or march back; or that our king will attack and the enemy king will retreat, or vice versa; or that our king will triumph and the enemy king will be defeated, or vice versa; and so there will be victory for one and defeat for the other.
dn1:1.23.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.’
dn1:1.23.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.24.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn1:1.24.2: This includes making predictions that there will be an eclipse of the moon, or sun, or stars; that the sun, moon, and stars will be in conjunction or in opposition; that there will be a meteor shower, a fiery sky, an earthquake, or thunder in the heavens; that there will be a rising, a setting, a darkening, a brightening of the moon, sun, and stars. And it also includes making predictions about the results of all such phenomena.
dn1:1.24.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.’
dn1:1.24.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.25.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn1:1.25.2: This includes predicting whether there will be plenty of rain or drought; plenty to eat or famine; an abundant harvest or a bad harvest; security or peril; sickness or health. It also includes such occupations as arithmetic, accounting, calculating, poetry, and cosmology.
dn1:1.25.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.’
dn1:1.25.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.26.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn1:1.26.2: This includes making arrangements for giving and taking in marriage; for engagement and divorce; and for scattering rice inwards or outwards at the wedding ceremony. It also includes casting spells for good or bad luck, treating impacted fetuses, binding the tongue, or locking the jaws; charms for the hands and ears; questioning a mirror, a girl, or a god as an oracle; worshiping the sun, worshiping the Great One, breathing fire, and invoking Siri, the goddess of luck.
dn1:1.26.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.’
dn1:1.26.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.27.1: ‘There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood.
dn1:1.27.2: This includes rites for propitiation, for granting wishes, for ghosts, for the earth, for rain, for property settlement, and for preparing and consecrating house sites, and rites involving rinsing and bathing, and oblations. It also includes administering emetics, purgatives, expectorants, and phlegmagogues; administering ear-oils, eye restoratives, nasal medicine, ointments, and counter-ointments; surgery with needle and scalpel, treating children, prescribing root medicines, and herbal bandages.
dn1:1.27.3: The ascetic Gotama refrains from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.’
dn1:1.27.4: Such is an ordinary person’s praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.27.5: These are the trivial, trifling details of mere ethics that an ordinary person speaks of when they speak praise of the Realized One.
dn1:1.27.6: The longer section on ethics is finished.
dn1:1.28.1: There are other principles—deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute—which the Realized One makes known after realizing them with his own insight. Those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.
dn1:1.29.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the first beginning, and assert various hypotheses concerning the first beginning on eighteen grounds.
dn1:1.29.2: And what are the eighteen grounds on which they rely?
dn1:1.30.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are eternalists, who assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal on four grounds.
dn1:1.30.2: And what are the four grounds on which they rely?
dn1:1.31.1: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect their many kinds of past lives.
dn1:1.31.2: That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
dn1:1.31.4: ‘The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
dn1:1.31.5: They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.
dn1:1.31.7: Because by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind I experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that I recollect my many kinds of past lives,
dn1:1.31.10: “The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
dn1:1.31.11: They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.”’
dn1:1.31.12: This is the first ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal.
dn1:1.32.1: And what is the second ground on which they rely?
dn1:1.32.2: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect their many kinds of past lives.
dn1:1.32.3: That is: one eon of the cosmos contracting and expanding; two, three, four, five, or ten eons of the cosmos contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
dn1:1.32.5: ‘The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
dn1:1.32.6: They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.
dn1:1.32.8: Because by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind I experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that I recollect my many kinds of past lives,
dn1:1.32.11: “The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar. They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.”’
dn1:1.32.12: This is the second ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal.
dn1:1.33.1: And what is the third ground on which they rely?
dn1:1.33.2: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect their many kinds of past lives.
dn1:1.33.3: That is: ten eons of the cosmos contracting and expanding; twenty, thirty, or forty eons of the cosmos contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
dn1:1.33.5: ‘The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
dn1:1.33.6: They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.
dn1:1.33.8: Because by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind I experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that I recollect my many kinds of past lives,
dn1:1.33.11: “The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar. They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.”’
dn1:1.33.12: This is the third ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal.
dn1:1.34.1: And what is the fourth ground on which they rely?
dn1:1.34.2: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin relies on logic and inquiry. They speak of what they have worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing their own perspective:
dn1:1.34.3: ‘The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
dn1:1.34.4: They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.’
dn1:1.34.5: This is the fourth ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely to assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal.
dn1:1.35.1: These are the four grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal.
dn1:1.35.2: Any ascetics and brahmins who assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal do so on one or other of these four grounds. Outside of this there is none.
dn1:1.36.2: ‘If you hold on to and attach to these grounds for views it leads to such and such a destiny in the next life.’
dn1:1.36.3: He understands this, and what goes beyond this. And since he does not misapprehend that understanding, he has realized quenching within himself.
dn1:1.36.4: Having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape from feelings, the Realized One is freed through not grasping.
dn1:1.37.1: These are the principles—deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute—which the Realized One makes known after realizing them with his own insight. And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.
dn1:2.1.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are partial eternalists, who assert that the self and the cosmos are partially eternal and partially not eternal on four grounds.
dn1:2.1.2: And what are the four grounds on which they rely?
dn1:2.2.1: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos contracts.
dn1:2.2.2: As the cosmos contracts, sentient beings are mostly headed for the realm of streaming radiance.
dn1:2.2.3: There they are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, wandering in midair, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.
dn1:2.3.1: There comes a time when, after a very long period has passed, this cosmos expands.
dn1:2.3.2: As it expands an empty mansion of divinity appears.
dn1:2.3.3: Then a certain sentient being—due to the running out of their lifespan or merit—passes away from that host of radiant deities and is reborn in that empty mansion of divinity.
dn1:2.3.4: There they are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, wandering in midair, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.
dn1:2.4.1: But after staying there all alone for a long time, they become dissatisfied and anxious:
dn1:2.4.2: ‘Oh, if only other beings would come to this place.’
dn1:2.4.3: Then other sentient beings—due to the running out of their lifespan or merit—pass away from that host of radiant deities and are reborn in that mansion of divinity in company with that being.
dn1:2.4.4: There they too are mind-made, feeding on rapture, self-luminous, wandering in midair, steadily glorious, and they remain like that for a very long time.
dn1:2.5.1: Now, the being who was reborn there first thinks:
dn1:2.5.2: ‘I am the Divinity, the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.
dn1:2.5.3: These beings were created by me!
dn1:2.5.6: “Oh, if only other beings would come to this place.”
dn1:2.5.7: Such was my heart’s wish, and then these creatures came to this place.’
dn1:2.5.8: And the beings who were reborn there later also think:
dn1:2.5.9: ‘This must be the Divinity, the Great Divinity, the Vanquisher, the Unvanquished, the Universal Seer, the Wielder of Power, God Almighty, the Maker, the Creator, the First, the Begetter, the Controller, the Father of those who have been born and those yet to be born.
dn1:2.5.10: And we were created by him.
dn1:2.5.12: Because we see that he was reborn here first, and we arrived later.’
dn1:2.6.1: And the being who was reborn first is more long-lived, beautiful, and illustrious than those who arrived later.
dn1:2.6.3: It’s possible that one of those beings passes away from that host and is reborn in this place.
dn1:2.6.4: Having done so, they go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
dn1:2.6.5: By dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind, they experience an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect that past life, but no further.

dn1:2.23.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are endless flip-floppers. Whenever they’re asked a question, they resort to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops on four grounds.
dn1:2.23.2: And what are the four grounds on which they rely?
dn1:2.24.1: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin doesn’t truly understand what is skillful and what is unskillful.
dn1:2.24.3: ‘I don’t truly understand what is skillful and what is unskillful.
dn1:2.24.4: If I were to declare that something was skillful or unskillful I might be wrong.
dn1:2.24.5: That would be stressful for me,
dn1:2.24.6: and that stress would be an obstacle.’
dn1:2.24.7: So from fear and disgust with false speech they avoid stating whether something is skillful or unskillful. Whenever they’re asked a question, they resort to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops:
dn1:2.24.8: ‘I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.’
dn1:2.24.9: This is the first ground on which some ascetics and brahmins rely when resorting to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops.
dn1:2.25.1: And what is the second ground on which they rely?
dn1:2.25.2: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin doesn’t truly understand what is skillful and what is unskillful.
dn1:2.25.4: ‘I don’t truly understand what is skillful and what is unskillful.
dn1:2.25.5: If I were to declare that something was skillful or unskillful I might feel desire or greed or hate or repulsion.
dn1:2.25.6: That would be grasping on my part.
dn1:2.25.7: That would be stressful for me,
dn1:2.25.8: and that stress would be an obstacle.’
dn1:2.25.9: So from fear and disgust with grasping they avoid stating whether something is skillful or unskillful. Whenever they’re asked a question, they resort to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops:

dn1:3.19.0: 3.2.5. Extinguishment of Suffering in This Life
dn1:3.19.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who speak of extinguishment in this life. They assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life on five grounds.
dn1:3.19.2: And what are the five grounds on which they rely?
dn1:3.20.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
dn1:3.20.2: ‘When this self amuses itself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation, that’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.’
dn1:3.20.3: That is how some assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life.
dn1:3.21.1: But someone else says to them:
dn1:3.21.2: ‘That self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.
dn1:3.21.3: But that’s not how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.
dn1:3.21.5: Because sensual pleasures are impermanent, suffering, and perishable. Their decay and perishing give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
dn1:3.21.6: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, this self enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. That’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.’
dn1:3.21.7: That is how some assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life.
dn1:3.22.1: But someone else says to them:
dn1:3.22.2: ‘That self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.
dn1:3.22.3: But that’s not how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.
dn1:3.22.5: Because the placing of the mind and the keeping it connected there are coarse.
dn1:3.22.6: But when the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, this self enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected. That’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.’
dn1:3.22.7: That is how some assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life.
dn1:3.23.1: But someone else says to them:
dn1:3.23.2: ‘That self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.
dn1:3.23.3: But that’s not how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.
dn1:3.23.5: Because the rapture and emotional elation there are coarse.
dn1:3.23.6: But with the fading away of rapture, this self enters and remains in the third absorption, where it meditates with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, “Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss”. That’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.’
dn1:3.23.7: That is how some assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life.
dn1:3.24.1: But someone else says to them:
dn1:3.24.2: ‘That self of which you speak does exist, I don’t deny it.
dn1:3.24.3: But that’s not how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.
dn1:3.24.5: Because the mental partaking of that as ‘blissful’ is said to be coarse.
dn1:3.24.6: But with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, this self enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness. That’s how this self attains ultimate extinguishment in this life.’
dn1:3.24.7: That is how some assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life.
dn1:3.25.1: These are the five grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life.
dn1:3.25.2: Any ascetics and brahmins who assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life do so on one or other of these five grounds. Outside of this there is none.
dn1:3.26.2: And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.
dn1:3.27.1: These are the forty-four grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the final end assert various hypotheses concerning the final end.
dn1:3.27.2: Any ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the final end do so on one or other of these forty-four grounds. Outside of this there is none.
dn1:3.28.2: And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.
dn1:3.29.1: These are the sixty-two grounds on which those ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the first beginning and the final end assert various hypotheses concerning the first beginning and the final end.
dn1:3.29.2: Any ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the first beginning or the final end do so on one or other of these sixty-two grounds. Outside of this there is none.
dn1:3.30.2: ‘If you hold on to and attach to these grounds for views it leads to such and such a destiny in the next life.’
dn1:3.30.3: He understands this, and what goes beyond this. And since he does not misapprehend that understanding, he has realized quenching within himself.
dn1:3.30.4: Having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape from feelings, the Realized One is freed through not grasping.
dn1:3.31.1: These are the principles—deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute—which the Realized One makes known after realizing them with his own insight. And those who genuinely praise the Realized One would rightly speak of these things.
dn1:3.32.0.1: 4. The Grounds For Assertions About the Self and the Cosmos
dn1:3.32.1: Now, these things are only the feeling of those who do not know or see, the anxiety and evasiveness of those under the sway of craving. Namely, when those ascetics and brahmins assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal on four grounds …
dn1:3.34.1: finite or infinite on four grounds …
dn1:3.35.1: or they resort to flip-flops on four grounds …
dn1:3.36.1: or they assert that the self and the cosmos arose anomalously on two grounds …
dn1:3.37.1: they theorize about the first beginning on these eighteen grounds …
dn1:3.38.1: or they assert that the self lives on after death in a percipient form on sixteen grounds …
dn1:3.39.1: or that the self lives on after death in a non-percipient form on eight grounds …
dn1:3.40.1: or that the self lives on after death in a neither percipient nor non-percipient form on eight grounds …
dn1:3.41.1: or they assert the annihilation of an existing being on seven grounds …
dn1:3.42.1: or they assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life on five grounds …
dn1:3.43.1: they theorize about the final end on these forty-four grounds …
dn1:3.44.1: When those ascetics and brahmins theorize about the first beginning and the final end on these sixty-two grounds, these things are only the feeling of those who do not know or see, the anxiety and evasiveness of those under the sway of craving.
dn1:3.45.1: Now, these things are dependent on contact. Namely, when those ascetics and brahmins assert that the self and the cosmos are eternal on four grounds …
dn1:3.47.1: finite or infinite on four grounds …
dn1:3.48.1: or they resort to flip-flops on four grounds …
dn1:3.49.1: or they assert that the self and the cosmos arose anomalously on two grounds …
dn1:3.50.1: they theorize about the first beginning on these eighteen grounds …
dn1:3.51.1: or they assert that the self lives on after death in a percipient form on sixteen grounds …
dn1:3.52.1: or that the self lives on after death in a non-percipient form on eight grounds …
dn1:3.53.1: or that the self lives on after death in a neither percipient nor non-percipient form on eight grounds …
dn1:3.54.1: or they assert the annihilation of an existing being on seven grounds …
dn1:3.55.1: or they assert ultimate extinguishment for an existing being in this life on five grounds …
dn1:3.56.1: they theorize about the final end on these forty-four grounds …
dn1:3.57.1: When those ascetics and brahmins theorize about the first beginning and the final end on these sixty-two grounds, that too is dependent on contact.
dn1:3.70.1: Now, when those ascetics and brahmins theorize about the first beginning and the final end on these sixty-two grounds, it is not possible that they should experience these things without contact.
dn1:3.71.12: Now, when those ascetics and brahmins theorize about the first beginning and the final end on these sixty-two grounds, all of them experience this by repeated contact through the six fields of contact. Their feeling is a condition for craving. Craving is a condition for grasping. Grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
dn1:3.72.1: When a mendicant truly understands the six fields of contact’s origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape, they understand what lies beyond all these things.
dn1:3.72.2: All of these ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the first beginning or the final end are trapped in the net of these sixty-two grounds, so that wherever they emerge they are caught and trapped in this very net.
dn1:3.72.3: Suppose a deft fisherman or his apprentice were to cast a fine-meshed net over a small pond. They’d think: ‘Any sizable creatures in this pond will be trapped in the net. Wherever they emerge they are caught and trapped in this very net.’
dn1:3.72.4: In the same way, all of these ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the first beginning or the final end are trapped in the net of these sixty-two grounds, so that wherever they emerge they are caught and trapped in this very net.
dn1:3.73.1: The Realized One’s body remains, but his conduit to rebirth has been cut off.
dn1:3.73.2: As long as his body remains he will be seen by gods and humans.
dn1:3.73.3: But when his body breaks up, after life has ended, gods and humans will see him no more.
dn1:3.73.4: When the stalk of a bunch of mangoes is cut, all the mangoes attached to the stalk will follow along.
dn1:3.73.5: In the same way, the Realized One’s body remains, but his conduit to rebirth has been cut off.
dn1:3.73.6: As long as his body remains he will be seen by gods and humans.
dn1:3.73.7: But when his body breaks up, after life has ended, gods and humans will see him no more.”
dn1:3.74.1: When he had spoken, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,
dn1:3.74.2: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! What is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”
dn1:3.74.3: “Well then, Ānanda, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Net of Meaning’, or else ‘The Net of the Teaching’, or else ‘The Divine Net’, or else ‘The Net of Views’, or else ‘The Supreme Victory in Battle’.”
dn1:3.74.4: That is what the Buddha said.
dn1:3.74.5: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
dn1:3.74.6: And while this discourse was being spoken, the ten-thousandfold galaxy shook.
